message+desc:
22-year old Canadian Vlogger Christian LeBlanc travelled around Asia in 2015 for 7 and a half months and had this to say: 

"...Every country has unique things to offer, but the Philippines is, by far, my favorite. I've never met a kinder group of people and a more beautiful landscape. The blues of waters, the most exaggerated landscapes, there is just so much to do!

"My time in the Philippines was unforgettable and i loved it so much that i'll actually be going back in 2016."

Check out his HONEST review of his visit to some of the Philippines' top destinations, including Bohol, Cebu, Palawan, and Siquijor, through this Vlog and we hope you too get to experience how MORE FUN it is in the Philippines!

P.S. Just some minor corrections and suggestions:

(1) On the duration of tourist visa:
a foreign traveller can actually stay in the Philippines visa-free for 30 days and not 21 days, as stated in the video.

(2) The whole of Mindanao is not unsafe and there are equally beautiful touristic destinations one could visit in there such as Siargao, which is becoming a world surf haven; Cagayan de Oro, known for the wild river rafting; Davao, where the Philippines' highest peak, Mt. Apo, could be trekked; Camiguin, where you could swim in a carbonated water, and many more! :-)

#VisitPhilippinesAGAIN2016If anyone is planning to go traveling to Southeast Asia, consider adding The Philippines to your list! 

YouTube: Christian LeBlanc
Instagram: LostLeBlanc
Snapchat: LostLeBlanc

The Philippines was the highlight of my trip and I will definitely be back.
Hope this video helps!

#ThePhilippines #ItsMoreFunInThePhilippines #Travel
comments:
I agree with Christian Leblanc and after visiting the Philipinnes for 6 weeks in September/ October 2014, I am actually moving there in 3 weeks ( the 1st week of February) I cannot wait to be among those wonderful people!$$I absolutely love the Philippines , this is a a great video , I have done a few of the things Christian had done , Cebu , Bohol , Dumagete , I am returning in Feb to do a little more , Kawasan falls,  and Palawan , can't wait !!$$My visit to Manila and QC...truly changed my life... The wonderful food and the kind generous people. Who showed me that I didn't need possessions to be happy. I help some street kids...and for the first time in my life.... I give of myself without expecting anything in return...but my joy was priceless üôèüèº.  I came back to US... But I left my heart in the Philippines ....God bless the Philippines.... Pinoy pride....üëçüèªüëçüèªüíØ$$I love all about the Philippines, but most if all its people, will be going there for a few weeks soon <3$$I love that you have shared this video The Philippines... it was an awesome video and full of great info! I noticed that in your caption you have highlighted "Corrections"... I think it would be great if you included in this that Mindanao as a whole isn't unsafe, and that many areas in Northern Mindanao can happily be explored and experienced as any other areas in the country.  

For example:

Camiguin is technically part of Mindanao... Cagayan de Oro where I live is part of Mindanao... Siargao (one of the biggest backpacking islands) is part of Mindanao. 

It would be great if you "stuck up for Mindanao" in your caption as well.  

Have a great day.$$Dean JB, Filipino hospitality is second to none, sometimes to a fault. We will kill our last pig to serve to our guests. Not sure why despite our beautiful country and wonderful people, our tourist arrivals are last among the South East Asian countries. Perhaps more people like you spreading the word will make a difference. Thank you again for your kind words for our country.$$I'm in total agreement to what you have said, Philippines is my favorite place - in fact I love the Philippines. message+desc:
English version: At TSL, we're part of the Speak Good Singlish movement. Simply because we believe things around the world will get done lot more quicker if everyone spoke a bit of Singlish. 

Singlish version: Singlish best dun believe watch this video la.

SEE WHAT I MEAN!!

Also read: http://thesmartlocal.com/read/food-trends
comments:
That chope move!! #winliaolor XDD$$This is a long post but just wanted to let some of my fellow Singlishers know. (This was in response to someone's comment about Singlish being inferior to English).

Singlish is a totally separate language system from English. It is neither an "accented" English, "lazy/broken" English, nor a "dialect".

A language system is not only defined by its vocabulary but also its pragmatics and universal grammaticular and audinal rules, which Singlish satisfies.

If you don't believe what I'm saying, I recommend you to read up some thesis publications especially in "Language and Development" regarding the establishment of Singlish as an entire new language system, which has since gained steam post 2008s as the progress and knowledge of human language development blossomed. Some of these were written and taught by multiple professors when I was in NUS, and they (foreign lecturers) were behind the stand that Singlish was innately a language, not a dialect.

Having established this, it is only natural if a foreigner is unable to understand us whilst in Singapore, the same way I wouldn't understand Tagalog if I were in Philippines or any other country, simply because it is another LANGUAGE, not a corruption of English.

I truly feel that Singaporeans need to take ownership of our beloved native language and enjoy its usage to the maximum. Do not be ashamed of it and do not let anyone make you feel that Singlish is inferior to English because it is not.

Cheers to all the Singlish speakers out there.$$Not bad but not a very accurate representation. The guy is just lo sor, nothing to do with singlish v english$$Still don sound natural leh.... espiacially wen ordering mcdonald. Gd effort  but abit over liao... :p$$I see, thats why i wasnt able to blend in when i was there lmao!$$Let me rephrase the Singlish version of the description in proper English that's equally short (8 words).

"Singlish's the best. Watch this if in doubt."$$Cariissa CC For the couple just now, don't understand chope right?! sb annoying. lol$$Ashley Lim Wow Mcdonalds is going all out to promote the burger...$$Whats with the can, can and can liao sia. So unnatural leh$$This explains so much!! Watch till the end Nicole Moussa Anthony Lown$$Jasper Tan this is the video that I told you this morning! Lol$$we cut things short...the art of summarisation.lol$$Dangerous place for time wasters! Nice one! #comeiclapforyou$$Lol. The last part with all those tissue papers.$$That chop... Omg epic.. #likeaboss$$Lol I didn't know cte pie can come out ecp 1 Hahaha$$I would try to avoid saying things like " can liao"$$I am not so sure about that.

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Boracay, Aklan

What is it?
Ah, Boracay. Need we say more? Since much has been said, raved and written about this famous four-kilometer stretch of powder white sand paradise, we would like to suggest you try the most exhilarating activity off it ‚Äî cliff-diving at Ariel's Point. The highest plank is about 15 meters high, which is as high as a five-storey building. But jump off and it ends with a safe, pleasantly wet landing. 

How to get there: 
Fly from Manila to Caticlan.

Or fly from Manila to Kalibo, then take a bus to Caticlan.

Or take a boat from Manila to Caticlan.

Fun Fact: 
Not a lot of people know that Tribal Adventure Day Tours are offered on this island. These are no ordinary tours. You spend an entire day getting to know the indigenous people living In the area. The women will welcome you into their homes and even cook for your group while you learn about their history and customs. Ask around for D'Arcy Kelly. He runs the show.

Photo by/Headline by: 
Tourism Department Philippines/Donna Dimayuga
comments: ^ America is the only country that calls "football" soccer, in Europe, Asia and everywhere else it is considered Football.$$Gelly Lizaso yup thats me

message+desc:
Kuta is a coastal town in the south of the island of Lombok, Indonesia. It has a spectacular scenery; cliffs and mountains reaching the coast to create jagged and awe-inspiring landscape and views. It well-known as one of the best surfing places in the world. Kuta Beach Lombok is one of tourist attractions; it has pristine white sand and transparent blue-greens in the water and well-known as surfer paradise.

#WonderfulIndonesia #PesonaIndonesia

message+desc: The Mobile Blood Bank came to us today to take our donations! After donating you get juice, 2 choco pies, and choice of small gift! Save lives and get free stuff. Sweet deal. KTO staff, get out and donate!!
comments:
Yep, the snacks are for heath purposes.  It's an amazing thing to eat two choco pies and be able to say it's "good for my health".  

Anemia? Oh my, are you okay now?

Marie$$I remember a funny ep. from the cartoon "6 teens" where the skater kept trying to give more blood all day because he wanted more free donuts and the stickers. He gave so much that he fainted from blood lost. He kept going in as a different person. Funniest spoof on giving blood.
I used to give all the time but now with the meds that I have to take for my Fibro, I am no long qualified to give. 
I only got the crappy cookies (usually not my favorite)-I want choco pies. That beats cookies any day.
If you are able to give blood, please do. They are always needing it, especially before a major holiday. (4th July is one of the deadliest in my area. Lots of accidents on that weekend by drunken drivers) So please give if you can.$$Are foreigners also allowed to donate? I remember in the 90ies it was not possible...$$There are a lot of restrictions and the language barrier can cause trouble, but if you speak Korean and haven't traveled abroad lately, body is in good condition, you can.  I just did (I'm Canadian)

Marie$$It's a great thing to do but the mobile van doesn't get to Castlemaine very often and I'm usually out of the country when it does.$$Shall we send ours to you Susan? :)$$Can foreigners donate the blood?$$@Leszek They can but there are many conditions. $$i.e. too many 'conditions'$$Where do I find out about it, I was a frequent donor in my country. I would like to continue in Korea (since I will stay here for a long time), but I don't know how to do it.$$Right now there is no information available in English, but actually, I am working on a project called Blood Connections

about an hour ago ¬∑ 
An Appeal to the United Nations from a former Filipino Delegate to the United Nations General Assembly

I am Michael Francis Acebedo Lopez, a Filipino and a former delegate to the United Nations General Assembly. Nearly ten years before the questionable rise of one Leni Robredo to the Philippine Vice Presidency, I had the honor of representing my country, the Philippines, as the youngest Filipino delegate to the United Nations General Assembly in its history. I also had the opportunity to be the Philippines‚Äôs first actual Youth Representative or Delegate, a partial fulfillment of our commitment to the UN‚Äôs World Programme of Action for Youth or WPAY. 

UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon accepted my letter of credential signed by the Philippine Foreign Minister. There it was stated that I was attending the General Assembly ‚Äúas Adviser to the Third Committee Plenary Session on Social Development, including questions relating to the World Social Situation and to Youth, Ageing, Disabled Persons and the Family.‚Äù In the august halls of the UN World Headquarters in New York, I also had the honor to draft and deliver the Philippine Statement to the General Assembly‚Äôs Third Committee. 

In light of Vice President Robredo‚Äôs video message to the UN Commission on Narcotic Drugs posted on TIME Magazine‚Äôs website and shared by various media organizations, I am recalling the mandate I was once given in an effort to reach out to all of you, member states of the UN and all organizations within the UN System. If said mandate is not sufficient because it has long since lapsed, I am hinging my appeal therefore on my being a natural born citizen of one of only four Asian nations who signed the 1945 Charter that created the United Nations. 

I am making this urgent appeal on behalf of each and every Filipino grossly misrepresented by our a Vice President in said video message, a Vice President whose own mandate has been called into question, with the highest electoral tribunal of the land, the Presidential Electoral Tribunal, having considered the election protest against her win to be sufficient in both form and substance. 

With unfounded claims and unsubstantiated allegations, Vice President Robredo wantonly painted an impossibly grim image of the Philippine situation if only to attract international attention and action. To say that she delved in speculation is understating the gravity of her made-up claims and the severity of the damage she has caused on our country and our people in so doing. In reporting to the world what she failed to report to Philippine authorities, assuming there are actual reports received by the Office of the Vice President, she has not only embarrassed our country, she has betrayed the public trust and committed economic sabotage, both punishable under Philippine laws. 

For her to say that ‚Äúour people feel both hopeless and helpless‚Äù is a brazen lie. Confidence in the presidency is at an all time high (while the same cannot be said of the vice president whose approval ratings continue to plummet); as a people, we feel hopeful and empowered like we‚Äôve never felt before. 

Please understand that at the heart of this is destructive party politics. It is the Vice President‚Äôs party flexing its muscles to overthrow a duly elected government so they may once more regain control of government. Perhaps she feels time is running out for her because of developments in the Presidential Electoral Tribunal. So she and her allies have launched an expensive campaign using human rights and the War on Drugs as their excuse to bait the world into interfering in our domestic issues. 

When the Vice President says 7,000 people have been killed in the President‚Äôs War on Drugs, she fails to mention that this is set against the backdrop of around 700,000 to one million successful arrests and surrenders. So the figure she presents to you is not even one percent. And surely with the sheer number of those involved in the illicit drug trade, some police operations see suspects resisting arrest and fighting back and the police having to defend themselves resulting in casualties. Every war has casualties. It is not a perfect war and I‚Äôm certain there have been abuses along the way, and these need to be looked into and those responsible must be brought to justice. But exaggerating things does not help at all. 

In asking for the international community, the UN, to intervene, she uses the issue of human rights. Let us then talk about human rights. 

In responding to the call of Robredo, the international community must tread carefully lest it encroaches on our very sovereignty and our right to self-determination. And as a sovereign state, we have determined to wage an internal war (not a war against another nation) against the evils of drugs, a direction affirmed by our democratic processes when President Duterte who included the War on Drugs as one of his main programs of action, received an overwhelming mandate during the May 2016 Presidential Election. In short, the War on Drugs, by extension, has the people‚Äôs mandate. 

Any effort to disturb our democracy and sovereignty as a response to the Vice President‚Äôs irresponsible and unfounded claims will subvert the will of the Filipino people and violate our Human Right of Suffrage enshrined in both the Philippine Constitution and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (Article 21 of the international covenant). 

Once again, I am making this appeal to all member states of the United Nations and all organizations within the UN System to disregard the Philippine Vice President‚Äôs statement which is, I reiterate, a grave misrepresentation of the prevailing sentiments of our people and a gross perversion of the facts surrounding the War on Drugs. 

To my fellow Filipinos, let us remain vigilant in the face of threats to our democracy by the very people who claim to defend it. Ako po‚Äôy nanawagan na i-share ang video na ito upang ito ay umabot sa UN at sa iba‚Äôt ibang foreign governments. 

Maraming salamat. Thank you and good evening.

Wanted to live there üíñüíñüíñ$$Yes , and we are back for 2 1/2 weeks in April$$Family bonding drinks at this place! Sean Allen

message+desc:
Okay I did not expect this. Great job Lee Bee Wah! It may not have been intentional, but because of the statement, a lot of people are aware about our water situation now.We can all agreet the statement on apprecaiting water was one of the silliest things we've heard. But let's think about it for a second. Did it actually work?

We asked people on the street whether the 30% hike in water prices will make them appreciate water more.

The answers will surprise you.
comments:
No.
But it makes people adjust their lifestyle.
What used to be generosity becomes petty.
What used to be socialising becomes occasion.
What used to be sharing becomes mind the bill!
It further distances society and increases selfishness and aloofness...
Sad outcomes.$$To make us appreciate oxygen more we should pay for fresh air too. What a distorted theory.$$Cut the MP salary 30% to make them appreciate their HIGH PAY job !!!$$Many people think they don't waste water..but probably a lot of people will think they wasted their vote....during last election

message+desc:
Chamba
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
There are many stunning, intriguing places around the world, but very few are as beautiful and awe-inspiring as Chamba. Located in the blossom of green mountains with perennial falls and streams, Chamba is one of those places that not only lives up to its image, but exceeds it. 
A travel to this place evokes many images... fairy-tale snow-capped mountain vistas, rushing torrent of the Ravi River and beautiful temples. One of the most famous hill stations in India that has been holding a magical allure for travellers, Chamba, a former princely state, is the administrative headquarters of the district of the same name. 
- See more at: http://incredibleindia.org/index.php/travel/destination/chamba

When Baker's Heart say they can make any kind of cake you imagine, they really mean it!

Started by Chef Zach in 2012, Zach was a one-man show for 2 years surviving on only 3 hours of sleep each night. He often had to sleep over at the bakery! 4 years on, Baker's Heart now serves up to 50 people a day, some of whom are celebrities and comprises of a team of 12 full-time staff. 

To celebrate SMEs which make up a surprising 99 per cent of businesses in Singapore, DBS has partnered us to put together a special series of videos as part of the 99% SME campaign launched by DBS and Singtel to support SMEs.
 
The campaign culminates with SME Week from 14 - 23rd Oct ‚Äì Baker's Heart is offering a special deal where you can get 30% off 500g Joyous Rainbow cake before 31 October 2016! More details here: https://www.99sme.sg/deal-detail/?id=268 

Head over to www.99sme.sg/special-deals to find out more. #SupportOurSMEs

message+desc: Ever wonder what happens at Seoul's Hangang River afterdark?  I went for a walk last night at around 11 pm last night and came across this scene.  Seoulites feel safe in their city, and they take time out to excercise even late. Walking, jogging, skateboarding, rollerblading, biking.  You name it!
comments:
amazing what people can do afterdark, there :) $$Oh I love walking down by the River at night it is soo peaceful and great skyline views$$i know! i went to Î≥¥ÎùºÎß§ one time at like 10, expecting it to be empty or nearly empty. Much to my surprise, it was packed! there was even a group of ÏïÑÏ£ºÎßàs doing an exercise class!! „Öã„Öã„Öã$$Isn't it usually packed until about midnight? I love going out late in Korea!$$sleepless night in seoul!!! $$DongDaeMun Market area doesn't even really get moving until about 11PM and then is rather active until 2 or 3AM$$Yeah, the wholesale area is full of people from around the country looking for inventory for their clothing stores into the wee hours.$$The South Korea is the most safest place to live and work, especially for children and for young people! I love South Korea~~$$When I first came to Korea, I went to the convenience store at around 11 at night.  I ended up exploring the back streets and suddenty thought...."Marie! You're in a new country! What are you doing out here in the dark by yourself?!"  And then I heard a sound right behind me!  I was so scared, I turned around and saw.... A pregnant woman pushing a baby stroller. Figured if even a woman with a baby and a half with her was confidently strolling around at this hour, I would be okay.  

And then I never worried again (but I'm still careful of course mom!).

Marie

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Davao, Mindanao

What is it like? 
Kadayawan Festival, the annual fiesta of Davao City, is celebrated during the third week of August. Highlights include floral floats, street-dancing competitions and exhibits that showcase the island's products.

Fun Fact: 
The celebration is a venue for celebrity sightseeing. Popular Philippine celebs who are based in Manila are known to fly all the way to the south just to be part of Kadayawan.

Photo by/Author: 
Tourism Department Philippines/Jao Bautista

message+desc:
The 10th Sanur Village Festival: Environment and Galvanizing Community Involvement

Sanur Village Festival promises lots of fun, delicious food and plenty of excitement and gaiety for everyone, where this year the emphasis will  be on galvanizing community involvement to care more for the Environment and the continuation of local arts and culture. The Environment program includes cleaning of the beaches from unsightly flotsam and trash, the sending off  of baby turtles to sea, and planting  of  new coral reefs off the coast, all of which  will involve primary and secondary school students, members of the travel industry and NGOs. http://goo.gl/A7T4Ju #WonderfulIndonesia
comments: Awesome  very interesting  :)

message+desc:

message+desc:
Where is it?
Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

What is it?
Mapawa Nature Park in Malasag, Cagayan de Oro is a protected 2,500-hectare area that that provides adventurous visitors with activities like horseback -riding, camping, saying hello to a 300-year old tree, jumping off from a 15-foot cliff and a river trek that could include rapelling or sliding down a waterfall!

Fun Fact:
You could lose a sandal during the river trek, but there's a big chance it will float back to land to return to you.

Photo by / Headline by:
Tourism Department Philippines / Nikki Golez

Tomorrow. Or now na. Will fly tonight then fly back the next night. message+desc:
Kausani - Peace among thickly forested lanes and Himalayan views
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Located 53 km. to the north of Almora, Kausani, the brithplace of Hindi poet Sumitra Nandan Pant, is a picturesque hill station famous for its scenic splendour and its spectacular view of the Himalayas. Situated at 6075 feet above sea level, atop a narrow ridge, Kausani is thickly forested and separated from the soaring Nanda Devi ranges by low mountains. In 1929, Mahatma Gandhi stayed here at the Anasakti Ashram.

- See more at: http://incredibleindia.org/index.php/travel/destination/kausani
comments: It is a historical place in lNDIA ? Its a nice place....

message+desc:
Where is it?
Obando, Bulacan

What is it?
Want a baby? Every year, single men and women and childless couples dance in the streets to seek help from the patron saints of matchmaking and fertility: Sta. Clara, San Pascual de Baylon and the Virgin of Salambao. 

Fun Fact:
Local fishermen and farmers join in the dancing as well but instead of praying for children, they ask for a good harvest! With all the dancing involved, it's almost impossible not to join in yourself, whatever your intentions may be! 

Photo from Norma Belleza--from the collection of Mr. & Mrs. Elmer Sarmiento
comments: what's so fun getting chanelas, and the broom.

message+desc:
Where is it?
Coron, Palawan

How to get there?
Fly from Manila to Busuanga, then transfer to a van bound for Coron.

What is it? 
Coron is one of the northern islands of the paradise province of Palawan (which is south of Manila). This island-municipality boasts emerald green bays, rivers lakes and beaches.

Fun Fact:
Snorkeling areas around the island are perfect locations for spotting Japanese shipwrecks.

Photo by/Headline by:
Tourism Department of the Philippines/Jao Bautista

They have airfare promos from P1...P28...P88...It's definitely More Fun in the Philippines!$$My late wife & i have a chance 2 visit the place we enjoyed it all the rest of Palawan....$$oh its a beautiful world  3:)$$Pa Feature naman yung sa Bais City , Negros Orriental. White sand din tapos Balconless :)

Where is it? 
Donsol, Sorsogon

What is it like? 
This small fishing town is famous for its gigantic residents, the 56-foot whale sharks. There, you can take a boat to the open sea and swim with these enormous but gentle beasts!

Fun Fact: 
Take a sunset bangka ride down the Donsol River to see thousands of fireflies light up the night. 

Photo by/Author: 
Mark Takazin/Nikki Golez

Where is it?
Bacolod City, Visayas

How to Get There:
"Fly from Manila or Cebu to Bacolod.

Or take a bus from Dumaguete to Bacolod.

Or take a boat from Manila to Bacolod."

What is it?
Known as the Festival of Smiles, Masskara started as a way of uplifting the spirits of the people of Bacolod.

Fun Fact:
Electric Masskara, a three-day portion of the three-week long celebration, is the longest street party in the country.

Photo by / Headline by:
Izah Morales / Rachel Teotico

Coron is the third largest island in the Calamian Islands in Northern Palawan.

Fly from Manila to Busuanga, then transfer to a van bound for Coron.

Visit the Maquinit Hot Springs for the perfect end to a day of island-hopping.

message+desc:
"They all" say you will get caught for eating and drinking on the bus, but knowing that's false now shouldn't turn us into inconsiderate commuters.There is no law against eating and drinking on the bus. That's a fact.

But should we do it? Of course not.

https://mustsharenews.com/eat-drink-buses/
comments:
Hah! Someone needs to educate the bus captains then. I used to take 855 from Yishun to Bt Merah every morning and to save time, would bring a bun for breakfast. I was always discreet, never littering, and most of the time, no one cared. One particular bus driver would not only shout at you, but if you didn't realise he was talking to you, would actually take the time while at a bus stop to walk all the way to the back to reprimand you for eating.$$You can treat the bus as a cafeteria so long as you don't welcome ants as passengers by dropping the bread crumbs. 

Also water and sweets are acceptable in the train. It will be cruel to leave someone thirsty in the train, and sweets are too small to make the train dirty$$Nice nice. I once saw someone opened a pack of economical noodle that smell so good right behind me on the bus. 
I'd like to invite anyone to join me for a durian and jackfruit fiesta in the bus.$$In the 90s, there used to be a no food and drink sign on the bus and there is indeed a penalty.  Currently these signs have been removed.$$As with all things in life, even if it's permissible be considerate in shared places.$$Once a bus driver who wasn't on duty ate fried rice and fried chicken in a container of course IN THE BUS BESIDE ME. Wow!$$Benji Tan NEED TO TAG YOU FOR THIS LOL

Sawara Iris Festival <June 1~June 30>
1.5 million irises bloom in the Sawara Aquatic Botanical garden, Sawara city, Chiba pref. 50~300 years-old traditional Japanese buildings still remain in Sawara area. You can enjoy historic atmosphere just 30 minutes away from Narita International Airport!
 
Sawara Area(Chiba) http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/chiba/sawara.html

message+desc: Summer is a firework season, and many fireworks display take place every week. Sumida River Fireworks display, one of the famous fireworks display in Tokyo will be held on this weekend. (28th)  And next week (Aug. 1 to 3) is Nagaoka Fireworks display at Nagaoka, Niigata pref. Wear Yukata (Summer Kimono), and enjoy the festivals! Photo courtesy: Niigata Prefecture, Nagaoka Fireworks display
comments: I recall my memory that enjoyed it with my ex-girlfriend almost every year. I miss it very much for 22 years since I permanently left Japan in 1990. I miss a hot spring bathing, too.$$The fireworks in Japan is so beautiful mostly in month of August or September is a fireworks event there so many people seeing a fireworks...$$This year AGAIN I will miss this :( I will arrive 1st of August... next time i will go I will travel a bit earlier so I can watch this amazing fireworks display too... that said, I will visit plenty of others in August too ^.^

message+desc:
Amarnath - Abode of Lord Shiva in the Snowy Himalayas

Located in one of the world‚Äôs most incredible landscapes of Lidder Valley in Kashmir, the cave shrine of Shri Amarnath is situated at an altitude of 3680 mts. Flanked by breathtaking snow-clad capped peaks, this Shiva shrine provides a wonderful opportunity to soak in the sacred energies of the Himalayas.

Each year in the month of Shravan (July-August) when the moon is full, thousands of yatris, as pilgrims are called, congregate here to worship a naturally formed ice Lingam, symbol of Lord Shiva.

The waxing and waning of the Lingam with the moon has remained a world marvel. According to popular belief it reaches the maximum height on the puranmashi (full moon) of Shravan which is the main day for Darshan. 

- See more at: http://www.incredibleindia.org/travel/destination/amarnath

I feel the crew has totally forgotten their service towards their paid passengers

message+desc:
Terletak di Magelang Jawa Tengah, 100 km barat daya Semarang, 86 km sebelah barat Surakarta dan 40 km barat laut Yogyakarta, Candi Borobudur tercatat sebagai monumen Buddha terbesar di dunia. Dibangun di masa Raja Samaratungga dari Wangsa Syailendra pada 824, 300 tahun sebelum Angkor Wat di Kamboja dan 400 tahun katedral-katedral di Eropa, Borobudur merupakan candi yang memiliki koleksi relief Buddha terlengkap dan terbanyak di dunia. http://ow.ly/S1ejf

#WonderfulIndonesia #PesonaIndonesia

This place is amazing. All of Indonesia is amazing! Would like to visit again soon...

message+desc:
Jodhpur - A romantic journey into the past
---------------------------------------------------------------------

Located almost on the edge of the Thar Desert, the city of Jodhpur was founded in 1459 by Rao Jodha, the chief of the Rathore clan of Rajputs and was the capital of the State of Marwar. 

Jodhpur is also known as the Sun City because the sun shines brightly here every day of the year, and as Blue City since most houses in the old part of the city are painted blue.
 
The forts and palaces, temples and havelis, culture and tradition, spices and fabrics, colour and texture, a booming handicrafts industry, all add up to make this historic city worth a visit. 

- See more at: http://incredibleindia.org/index.php/travel/destination/jodhpur
comments: akshay kumar should brand ambassoder of incredible India

message+desc:
The Sambhar Lake, located in #Rajasthan, is the largest saline lake in India. The lake, popularly known as the ‚ÄòGift from Thar desert‚Äô, is mentioned in the mythological epic, ‚ÄòMahabharata'. It produces 2,10,000 tonnes of salt annually, making it one among the three leading salt-producing states in India. The 5.1 km long sandstone dam, which divides the lake basin, helps in salt production. 

The Salt laboratory and the Salt museum are really worth a visit.

Candi Prambanan is a 9th ‚Äì century Hindu temple in Central Java Indonesia, dedicated to the Trimurti; the expression of God as the creator, the Preserver, and the Destroyer. As the largest Hindu temple in Southest Asia, the temple which located about 17 kilometres (11 mi) northeast of the City of Yogyakarta on the boundary between Central Java and Yogyakarta Provinces is an icon of Indonesia‚Äôs cultural heritage and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. http://indonesia.travel/sites/site/247/prambanan

message+desc:
The Albert Hall Museum or the Government Central Museum is the oldest museum in #Rajasthan. Designed in 1876 by Colonel Sir Swinton Jacob, the building was constructed for welcoming King Edward VII, the Prince of Wales, on his visit to India. 

Situated amidst the beautiful gardens of Ram Niwas Bagh in Jaipur, the museum has an exquisite collection of rare articles including carpets, textiles, paintings, metal and wood crafts, pottery, arms and weapons, toys, dolls and even an Egyptian mummy from the Ptolemaic Epoch. 

The museum was opened for public in 1886. With its magnificent archways, courtyards, and towers, the museum stands testimony to the rich architectural heritage of the country. Needless to say, the museum offers a splendid visual feast for tourists and history connoisseurs.
comments: Awesome creation ,so beautiful$$Shows the old talent and skills our people had, I hope this will be revived again after all the bombardment from west!

message+desc:
1 in 8 Singaporeans have diabetes. The average Singaporean consumes 23 teaspoons of added sugar a day. Let that sink in for a while. 

The majority of them get this due to lifestyle choices and diet. Most people don't know that harmless looking food such as processed cereal, pasta sauce and cocktails are loaded with sugar. But with this video, you'll now know! :)

Rosalyn Lee (Official) shows you 9 facts you need to know about sugar that may save your life.
comments:
Processed carbs are technically simple sugars too.

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Bantayan Beach, Cebu

What is it? 
Bantayan once served as a Spanish base against Moro invasions. That's why a walk around can transport you centuries back. You can see traces of its heritage in the old Spanish-era houses and dilapidated fort ruins. Mangroves and palm trees line the shores of Sugar Beach, Paradise Beach and Virgin Island.

How to get there: 
Fly into Cebu from Hongkong, Singapore, Narita, Incheon, or any major Philippine city.

Or take a bus to Cebu from either Dumaguete or Bacolod. Or take your car via a Roll-On Roll-Off (RORO) ferry.

Or take a boat to Cebu from Manila or any major city in Visayas and Mindanao.

Then take a bus or shuttle from Cebu City to Hagnaya, then a ferry to the port of Sta. Fe.

Fun Fact: 
This island's watchtowers gave it the name ‚ÄúBantayan sa Hari‚Äù (Watchtower of the King). This was later shortened to ‚ÄúBantayan,‚Äù the name it's known as today.

Photo by/Headline by: 
George Tapan/Donna Dimayuga

Had such a lovely time there last year....will be back again.$$Been there amazing miss philippines so much$$Imiss that place so much..
;);;;;;$$i miss that place too$$Been there, I want to retire there$$so nice I will go and visit cebu for sure.,$$yes its a beautiful place..and its near from my hometown$$sugar beach,  been there$$Been there... amazing place :)

message+desc: Cibodas Botanical garden covering an 85 hectare area built in 1852 by Johannes Ellias Tijsmann,lies at the entrance of the Mt. Gede-Pangrango National Park at an altitude of 1,300 meters to 1,425 meters above sea level. It has a collection of 1,293 species of plants, 144 types of lichens, and 1,826 herbariums. Besides being sprawling gardens for tourists to enjoy and relax, Cibodas is mainly a center for conservation, research and education on the environment http://bit.ly/LeMm6s

message+desc:
Short trip to Yokohama 
Today‚Äôs photo is a Chinatown and Minatomirai in Yokohama.
Yokohama is one of the first Japanese cities that opened up to foreign residents during the Meiji Restoration (1868-1911) and now is a busy port city with numerous historic buildings as well as shopping and amusement facilities.
The Tokyu Toyoko Line and the Metro Fukutoshin Line have been connected since last March. You can go to Yokohama from Tokyo for the shortest 32 minutes without changing trains! There are many things to see around Kanto Area including Tokyo and Yokohama! 

One-day Trip Yokohama: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/routes/g_route/golden_tokyo_03.html
Tokyo Metro Subway Map
http://www.tokyometro.jp/en/subwaymap/

message+desc:
Located in Thailand is a village that looks strikingly similar to Italy!

Unlike the usual night markets and crowded streets of Thailand, Palio Village is a breath of fresh air that looks nothing like what you're used to. Explore the Italian-themed village which has incredibly realistic decor and architecture, great for taking photos to trick your friends. There are also souvenir shops, fashion botiques, cafes and bakeries around for a day of shopping!

Address: 
146/1 Moo.4, Thanarath Road (km.17), Moo-si, Sub-District, Pakchong District, Nakornratchasima 30130

Find out more about Palio Village and Khao Yai here: http://thesmartlocal.com/read/khao-yai

Where is it?
Samar, Eastern Visayas

What is it?
Samar is always wet, with downpours throughout the year. No wonder the region's rainforests are lush and healthy.

Spanish explorer Ruy Lopez de Villalobos set foot on the island in 1543 and named it Las Islas Filipinas.

message+desc:
It's a Filipino tradition that on New Year, your table has to have 12 fruits that are round for good luck. Some believe you have to have 12 different kinds of fruits, while others believe that you need at least 12 grapes. 

What kind of fruits did you put on your table this year?
comments: I think it's 13 round fruits not 12 :-)$$actually, it can be 13, 12 or 8 fruits. all of them are considered lucky according to the Chinese. We only had 8 kinds of round fruits on ours. :)

message+desc:
On Monday, we published a video on our YouTube channel in which some of us tried Indian Snacks from Little India. 

It was our intention to create a video celebrating Deepavali, but because of the poor execution of the video, we ended up offending a sizeable community of fellow Singaporeans.

The video should never have been produced and we removed it as soon as we realised our mistake.

The feedback we've received over the past 2 days have been vital in helping us identify our shortcomings. This is a big learning lesson we'll take with us moving forward.

We apologise again for this mistake and we will not be producing content like this again.
comments:
That's okay! The video was made with good intentions. Stuff just went wrong along the way. But thanks for trying! üòä$$just in case some of you missed it. singaporeans try is the name of one of their show and they have others like pretty smart, talk on the street etc. it can be singaporeans try: indian snacks, singaporeans try: chinese snacks or singaporeans try: whatever. you get the idea. regardless whether it‚Äôs chinese, malay, indian or caucasian in the title, it is just an adjective. if you felt offended because it‚Äôs racist, it‚Äôs just like saying the statement, i feel like eating malay food for lunch, is racist. tell me how would you describe the snacks that they tried in the video? 

regarding the content, if one gives a blank look when asked about a festive celebration doesn‚Äôt equate to being racist. i vaguely remember TSL doing a video on chinese new year or some chinese festival and the participants(mostly chinese) have no clue to most of the questions asked. so are they dissing their own race? their videos are meant to create awareness for the mass and some comments have forced them to take it down. this has in turn taken away the opportunity that this video has for other to learn about snacks some of us don‚Äôt even know existed. i hope i did not step on anyone‚Äôs toe with this comment. TSL, don‚Äôt be discouraged by this incident. you guys have been doing a great job.$$Had been an avid fan of the smartlocals videos as they never fail to put a smile on people's faces with their quirky content.

I had the fortune or the misfortune of watching the video that has since been taken down. I must say that It is rather sad that content was created to make people laugh at the expense of a community.

Furthermore, it just highlights the blatant privilege that exists in Singapore, and I guess that privilege is widely abundant in the smart local as well.

This ultimately point to not only a failure of the system that allowed for the creation and release of such content, but the greater ignorance that must have been present in the organization.

I hope thesmartlocal will understand that Singapore is not only defined by it's ethnic majority and that the minority groups are also part of the community. We don't deserve to be treated like outsiders to be tasted, sampled and critiqued.$$I've come to love you guys a lot. Your videos are always sincere in nature with good local content. I did not managed to watch the video to actually decide if it is truly negative in nature. If it really is as what the social media is painting it to be, it really is out of character for you guys. I hope you guys can truly learn from this and continue to be the awesome content creator in YouTube.$$Combating racism by classifying everybody according to their race & encouraging professional victimhood. illiberal means of preventing free exchange of ideas. what trigger happy singaporeans.

Rather than be quick to remove said video, keep it online for everyone to watch, to encourage an open dialogue about race.$$Dear smart local, don't stop producing awesome stuff! We make mistakes in life. Gotta move forward. People fly off the hook so easily, you Ë∑≥ËøõÈªÑÊ≤≥‰πüÊ¥ó‰∏çÊ∏Ö.$$Smart Local, I enjoy most of your contents, creative indeed. I have not seen the deepavali video, however, hope you guys can do another video with proper content and theme to cheer up deepavali. cheers$$For those wondering what was wrong with the video, this article explains it quite succinctly: http://mothership.sg/2016/10/the-smart-local-ruins-deepavali-for-sporean-indians-with-insensitive-racist-video/
Apart from the disdainful faces and comments, this line pretty much sums up why the video was so ridiculous: "the most adverse connotation of the video was the treatment of Indians as if they are foreign to Singapore, to be sampled and passed judgement on."$$Well guys, it's hard to not learn from it. Don't call food from someone else's culture diarrhea or anything along those lines ... 
and also... don't get ah lians (esp those with 0 sensitivity) for your videos please.$$If you were racist, apologise for your racism. Otherwise you're just missing the point and fucking up more. "Poor execution"? Is a piss poor euphemism for what your video actually was, which was racist.$$When you have a team that is filled with Chinese majority, such "incidents" are the norms.

Nothing but toxic.$$TSL: so you are sorry because video was not good and poor execution and etc etc. that is why you are apologizing. But you are not sad and apologetic that you hurt the sentiments of a minority community who is as much Singaporean as others and you had audacity to just mock them and their culture and make fun or look down on them ???? How ironic, is that what your culture and values teaches you? Have you even thought if such thing would happen to you or your culture and cultural festivities then how angry, upset or sad you would feel ??? Food for thought for those on your team who could be so boldly racist, provocative and insensitive...even here in Singapore. Shame on such folks.$$This is was supposed to be a celebration of Diwali - the festival of all festivals for Indians. There is nothing celebratory about racism. This just made the divide between races That much clearer. The ignorance was sickening. I have no idea how you fathomed this was okay. Did you actually think this was funny? 

Apologise for your racist video. 
Own up to that. There is no going around the fact that this was blatantly racist.$$"Poor execution"? Why - was comparing Indian food to diarrhea meant to be said in interpretive dance?$$The word 'sorry' isn't even in here. This entire thing looks so corporate..like you know the general PR template used to fight fire. 

Apology Not personal enough really aka not sincere enough. Yet the video has hit a personal spot with the associated people.$$I did spot some flaws in the video but didnt think it would blow up. Was puzzled too they made a video abt Deepavali but I didnt spot any local Indian in the vid..$$how was such blatantly insulting content get through the editorial in the first place?! mind boggling! üò° it's an insult to the wide spectrum of cultural diversity in Singapore that you don't deserve to claim to be so Smart about.$$You should re-upload it again. 
This time, to show proof and concrete evidence that Racism and Chinese Privilege still exist.$$I'm a huge fan of TSL, but really, this is so disappointing. This is exactly why you need an Indian in your team as well to avoid these kinda screw ups.$$I seriously think there has been an unnecessary hoohah over this video. TSL should not have deleted the video and let more people watch this and form their own opinion of it instead of succumbing to the few who watched and protested. In fact, thanks to this video, I learnt of a few Indian snacks which I have not heard of and I can't wait to try them. Give these kids a break. Peace, Out.$$Donovan, for goodness sake stop trying to promote your stupid fb entry lah. It's embarrassing; using this post to gain traction on urs.$$Admin: you should name ur pg as TheStupidLocal. com That sound better.$$Does anyone have a link to the video!? How bad can the video be!? I'm curious!$$TheSmartLocal.com I'm pretty aghast to see the kinds of posts which you are responding to, and the posts which you are liking (it's terribly easy to observe this). It makes me harbour more than a little doubt about how sincere your apology is.$$Not sure why there is a need for TheSmartLocal.com to apologise. Also not sure why the people commenting here are perceiving this as a "mistake". The "facts" of this entire saga is based on the dubious hearsay of one news site and some stray Facebook comments, since literally no one's watched the video that was taken down. If anyone reading this is interested to see what I mean, read what I already wrote and tell me again that you disagree. https://www.facebook.com/donovan.choy/posts/10210855810741367?pnref=story

Sheesh.

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Anilao, Batangas

What is it like? 
Found south of Manila, Anilao is a popular destination for snorkelers and divers because of its diversity of fish and corals.

How to get there: 
Take a bus to Batangas from Cubao or Pasay.

Fun Fact: 
The municipality of Mabini ‚Äì which Anilao belongs to ‚Äì has a surprising number of Mediterranean-inspired houses. Close to 15% of the population works in Italy.

Photo by/Author: 
Kevin Palmer/Cecile Golez

message+desc:
As one of the most widely celebrated Muslim holidays in the Philipines, the Eid'l Fitr on July 17 refers to the end of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan, which is the 9th month in the Islamic calendar. 

Originated by the Islamic Prophet Muhammad, Eid'l Fitr is a cause for celebration and thanksgiving to Allah. It was proclaimed a national holiday in the Philippines since 2002, and was the first predominantly Christian country to do so. This proclamation was intended to foster peace and goodwill between major religions in the Philippines. Most Filipino-Muslims gather together on this day to celebrate the month long feast of Ramadan.

message+desc:
Spotlight: Benedicto Cabrera, better known as Bencab, is a painter and a National Artist for visual arts. He was born in Malabon but now lives in Baguio where he put up the Bencab museum featuring his own works, works of other masters, and exhibitions of new contemporary artists. 

Photo of the BenCab Museum taken from ourawesomeplanet.com
comments: Been here on the way to Asin Spring. Nice paintings and lots of native wood carvings.$$Must visit in Baguio. Very interesting collection of art.

message+desc:
Shizuoka is famous as a home of green tea as well as Mt. Fuji.
The procession called ‚ÄúSUNPU-HONYAMA OCHATSUBO DOCHU GYORETSU‚Äù will be held on October 26th. 
It is a recreation of historical event in the 16th century.

Every spring, as first tea of the season is picked, the fresh tea is stored in ‚ÄúOCHATSUBO‚Äù, tea urn and during summer, the tea urn is kept and made ripened in a warehouse. 
Then in late October, the tea urn is carried to Kuno-zan Tosho-gu shrine and dedicated. The procession starts at 10 am.

Related Information
Shizuoka Area:
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/shizuoka/shizuoka_city.html
Kuno-zan Tosho-gu Shrine:
https://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/spot/shritemp/kunozantoshogu.html

message+desc:
Where is it?
Boracay, Aklan

How to Get There:
Fly from Manila to Caticlan. 

Or fly from Manila to Kalibo, then take a bus to Caticlan. 

Or take a boat from Manila to Caticlan.

What is it like?
When packing your bags for Boracay Island, shoes should be the least of your concerns. You'll be walking barefoot on the powder-fine sand most of the time. And sitting on it. And getting massages on it. You'll form quite an attachment to Boracay sand. Just please don't take any of it home! Leave the beach for others to enjoy.

Fun Fact:
Come dusk, young boys and girls take to the beach to begin sculpting impressive pieces of sand art. For a small fee, they can even personalize the sand art for you!

Photo by / Caption by:
Ryder Aquino / Nikki Golez
comments: Borakay is a beautiful place for having a rest. I advise evryone to discover this little island for you!!!

[New] 11 Obscure Getaway Locations in South-East Asia With Amazing Potential

Call the TIC ladies and they will do their best to help!*^^*Knowledgeable and helpful staff provide assistance in Korean, English, Japanese, or Chinese to ensure each caller has a worry-free travel experience. Butuan, Caraga

What is it like? 
The balangay is the first wooden boat to ever have been found in Southeast Asia. Butuan City has a Balangay Shrine that houses several of these ancient boats. The city also hosts a Balangay Festival every May.

message+desc:
The magical Lake Sentani offers the breathtaking scenery of Papua. The lake is a tropical, shallow, and at low-altitude which located at the Northeast of the Intan Jaya Regency, it is about 20 kilometres (12 mil) from the Capital, Jayapura City. The lake, which is considered by the local population as the home of the rainbows, is part of the Cyclops Strict Nature Reserve and contains many species of fish that cannot be found anywhere else in the world. Rainbow fish mostly are visible only after a hard rain, but in Lake Sentani they are visible all the time. http://ow.ly/RUTF9

#WonderfulIndonesia #PesonaIndonesia
comments: Wow...had the privilege of seeing the magical lake!!

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Masbate, Bicol

What is it like? 
Over 400 cowboys join the Masbate Rodeo every year, and compete for five days. Bull riding, street wrestling, whip cracking and load-carrying are just some of the events in this massive festival.

Fun Fact: 
There are usually 250 heads of cattle and 50 bulls in the rodeo.

Photo by/Author: 
Tourism Department Philippines/Meggy De Guzman

Proud to be masbatenio...$$One evident of western culture in asia$$Would love to visit Masbate, never been there yet!$$Love phillipines soon.$$You are all Welcome here at the Rodeo Capital of the Philippines - Masbate - It's more fun in Masbate ! ;) Rodeo Festival 2015 (whole month of APRIL).$$Wow proud to say masbatenia$$Proud to be masbatena....

message+desc:
In Furano, Hokkaido, there are many flower gardens and you could enjoy various kinds of flowers in summer.
Especially, lavender fields are well-known in this area and the best season is usually from mid-July to late July.
Don't miss the best season and enjoy the magnificent views!!

message+desc: A significant Buddhist centre, Bodhgaya #Bihar, is the place where the young and noble prince, Siddhartha, attained enlightenment to become Gautama Buddha, the founder of Buddhism. Thousands of pilgrims from across the world visit #Bodhgaya every year for study, prayer and meditation. Inside the Mahabodhi Temple complex, a UNESCO world heritage listed site, flourishes the large and historic bodhi tree. Immerse yourself in pure divinity and embrace absolute inner peace.
comments: its really incredible one of the centre of peace

What is it?
Cocoa Beach Island Resort is a sprawling 10-hectare paradise with crystal clear waters lined by coconut trees and wooden bungalows. The resort has four restaurants, a tennis court, two swimming spools and a spa.

Fun Fact:
A "service family" who live close to your cottage will take care of you during your stay at the  resort. They offer baby-sitting services for three hours, and even a full-time nanny to take care of the kids.

message+desc:
"I live for the road. Collecting experiences, versus that of materialistic belongings, will always be a goal of mine. This thought has always intrigued me, mostly because of the sense of appreciation for each. When it comes to experiences, we tend to only understand their importance in the long run. In the moment, we can of course enjoy them. However we may not be able to fully absorb their effect on us until much later on. On the other hand, materialistic belongings have their biggest value when first acquired. Like your mobile phone, for instance. The prized possession you couldn't take your eyes off of the day you brought it home, but has since become just another thing you have, and use. This is what propelled me to start traveling this past year, and I haven't looked back.

"As a filmmaker, photographer and avid traveler, I aspire to inspire through my work, both from my home base in the U.S. and around the globe.

"From the electric blue waters and lush palm forests, to the generous and heartwarming locals, there's no place quite like The Philippines. Having the opportunity to travel here and become immersed in its charm is an experience I cherish."

Words and Photo by: Mike Quinn 
https://facebook.com/michaelgquinn
comments:
I agree.... I find that my possessions have control of my life.... But I meet my true love on Bohol... She showed me how to find happiness without possessions .... I have been blind for so many years.... Now I know what is important in this life.....the beautiful gurl from the island show to me .... Praise God ...,my life forever change.....$$Yes i agree. I went to visit the Philippines last February 2016 and i realized i have missed so much. I have ro let my cousins pinch me to realize i am not dreaming. Being with my relatives so close to nature gave me happiness beyond compare. I will go back again but this time with my husband for him to feel the same because we both love the simple life and enjoy the beauties of the Philippines. So proud of you Philippines!!!$$Retired to Cebu City from San Francisco Bay Area about a year & half ago. Have been to Bohol several times and all over Cebu, the roads here are custom made for motorcycles, the coastal and mountain roads. Got about 7,000 islands yet to visit! I love it here, an affordable paradise.$$God bless you as you travel and appreciate God's creations! Blessed are you for having the opportunity to be with nature and giving its importance! Have a safe trek!
Thanks be to God for your  provisions and protections . message+desc: The majestic phinisi schooners are built by South Sulawesi's Bugis ethnic group. These ships have sailed Indonesia's seas for centuries. The Bugis are known as master shipbuilders and superb mariners. Back in the day, they were also greatly feared as fierce pirates. Fancy a ride? Well you may just have a chance to act as a pirate on-board because you can charter your own private schooner or participate in a diving expedition and liveaboard on a traditional phinisi schooner. #WonderfulIndonesiaSince earliest times of human settlement in the Indonesian archipelago, her seas have been natural lanes of migration, communication and commerce. Not surprisingly, therefore, that up to this day the islands have  inherited perhaps some of the most sophisticated maritime traditions in the world. Her...

message+desc:
We found a Halal Certified London themed cafe in Bugis!

Located in a quaint corner of Bugis is Richmond Station - Singapore's ONLY Halal-Certified British cafe! Apart from serving classic English fare like Fish Pie, they also have some innovative dishes like Crab Benedict and Laksa Pasta with Mussels & Caviar.

message+desc:
Apl.de.Ap took his friends to discover the beautiful landscapes that the Philippines has to offer! Make sure to watch the video to see all the wonderful places they visited.

#ItsMoreFunInThePhilippinesThe Philippines will always be home, and I feel forever fortunate to call it as such. The people, the food, the sights, it‚Äôs something that everyone has to experience. Recently, I was lucky enough to bring some great friends back to experience the Philippines for the first time, and for others, to become reacquainted with the islands. 

Over the next several months, we‚Äôre going to showcase some of the best that the country has to offer, and see why ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs More Fun in the Philippines.‚Äù 

www.facebook.com/famcore

#ItsMoreFunInThePhilippines #tpbgovph #PhilippineAirlines
comments:
I am humble to say that we've been to most of these places. It makes me smile and brings back all the good times we had on our summer vacation. Our best trip ever in The Philippines with our family. Philippines is a beautiful country. We have a lot of things to offer  if the government will pay attention to tourism.$$So good to go to bolinao pangasinan away from tourists! Future home! Studied so much about this country..Much history those Pinoy/Americans know very little about their home country & the past that Pilipinos went through with Spain & the US, yet coming out of that dark era they became such humble caring lovely people, as they always were trading peacefully & tribal for thousands of years, with ancient writings and connections as far as Morroco & India who settled in this country long before the Spanish. It is an endless wonder & mystical.. The OFWs here in Australia are not like the Pilipino people you meet in the Provence.. As a Kiwi/ New Zealander/Aotearoa I can relate to many things in Philippines. The Seafood & fresh organic produce and happy people...The singing, the diversity of culture! Can't wait to leave Australia one day for the Philippines!$$Truly amazing!! We took our first family trip there this past summer and stayed in Palawan. It was absolutely stunning!$$Coron, the small paradise shows the endless beauty of the Philippines. Please share if you like it!

message+desc:
Snap pictures of sightings of Korea and enter your photo to the Snapshot Korea Photo Contest.

More info in the post below.<<Snapshot Korea>>
Photo contest campaign hosted by the Korea Tourism Organization (KTO) and the Voluntary Agency Network of Korea (VANK)

Look at your surroundings for familiar sightings of Korea.
A hard-working Korean friend. 
Your latest favorite Korean drama.
These are all sightings of Korea that exist in various places of the world. 
Public diplomacy group VANK and the Korea Tourism Organization are collaboratively hosting the ‚ÄúSnapshot Korea‚Äù photo contest.
Snap pictures of sightings of Korea in your everyday surroundings and enter your submission!

<Participation Requirements>
Participants: Non-Korean citizens (residence does not matter)
Submission Deadline: August 6, 2013 ‚Äì September 30, 2013
Entry Details: Take snapshots of random sightings of Korea and the spread of Korean culture within in your everyday life or surroundings.
Examples)
- A close Korean neighbor or friend
- Globalization of Korean (pictures of people studying Korean)
-Yourself watching a Korean drama in your room

<Participation Details>
1) Snap your picture
2) Write a short caption of 250 characters (English, including spaces)
3) Post the photo, caption, and email address to the ‚ÄúPhoto Contest: Snapshot Korea‚Äù Facebook Page
(If you do not use Facebook, please feel free to email your entry to smartdiplomacy@prkorea.org)

<Judging Criteria>
Originality of picture and caption = 30 points
Depth and sincerity = 30 points
Fulfillment of requirements = 20 points
Participation on Facebook page = 20 points

<Winners Announcement: October 10, 2013>
100 winners will be selected and given the title of Honorary Korea Ambassadors by VANK and the Korean Tourism Organization. Contest winners will receive an official certificate of recognition and a bundle gift pack filled with souvenirs of Korean culture, history, and famous locations. 
__________________________________________________________

<VANK>
The Voluntary Agency Network of Korea‚Äôs vision is for Korea to develop into the hub of Asia, the gateway to Northeast Asia, and a loved country that shares friendships and dreams with people from all over the world. Our mission is to help youth improve Korea‚Äôs national prestige, play a role in making the world a better place, and realize their own dreams through these efforts.

<Korea Tourism Organization>
Corporate Philosophy: To improve quality of life in Korea and spread Korean culture worldwide through the strengthening and development of the tourism industry.
Vision: A global public enterprise that promotes Korea as a world class travel destination
 _____________________________________________________________

<Contact Us>
Email: smartdiplomacy@prkorea.org
Facebook: www.facebook.com/snapshotkorea

message+desc:
Where is it? 
University of the Philippines, Diliman, Quezon City

What is it like? 
‚ÄúThe Oblation‚Äù is the popular icon of the University of the Philippines. It‚Äôs a concrete sculpture of an almost naked man facing skyward with his arms outstretched. The statue symbolizes selfless dedication to the nation.

How to get there: 
Fly into Manila through one of more than 30 international airlines. You can also fly in from any major Philippine city.                                        Or take a bus from any major city in Luzon.                                                Or take a boat from any major Philippine port.                                                  Then take a taxi, jeepney or bus to Quezon City.

Fun Fact: 
To celebrate the university‚Äôs 100th anniversary, some of its alumni launched an art exhibit called ‚Äú100 Nudes / 100 Years,‚Äù inspired by the Oblation.

Photo by/Author: 
Rizza Garcia/Brandon Dollente

Only Filipino Citizens can enjoy this academic freedom .$$i‚Äôm a product of this university! ‚Äúuniversity of the philippines‚Äù

message+desc:
Where is it?
Apo Island, Negros Oriental

How to Get There:
"Fly from Manila to Dumaguete.

Or take a bus from Cebu to Oslob, then take the Roll-On Roll-Off (RORO) ferry to Dumaguete.

Or take a boat from Cebu or Tagbilaran to Dumaguete.


Then take a bus from Dumaguete to Zamboanguita, and transfer to an outrigger boat to take you to Apo Island."

What is it?
Only seven of the 220 species of turtles around the world are considered marine or saltwater. And five of those species can be found in the Philippines.

Fun Fact:
Unlike land turtles, pawikans (marine turtles) cannot retract their head and limbs under their shells.

Photo by / Headline by:
Tourism Department Philippines / Rey Tiempo
comments: Nice place.. see http://explorephilippines.org/destination/apo-island

message+desc: This is the Old Silay Port in Negros Occidental. Built in 1933, it was one of the longest wharfs in Asia, but was struck during the Japanese occupation. Still, a sight to behold as this photo by Patrick Sy suggests. If you have travel photos, videos or blog posts you‚Äôd like to share, send us a PM for a shot at being featured soon!
comments:
The area is surrounded by Urban Poor Community. Very friendly and really proud of the landmark that they will offer to accompany and guide you. If you have plans of going, wear shorts and slippers. A bit muddy that we walked barefooted. At the time we went there sky wasnt that great but we decided to shoot anyway. It was really worth it. Also check for tides, low tide would be best to get that nice reflection.

ISO100 ∆í/16 60" (1 minute)$$This is the old Spanish port of Silay that was built in 1894, not in 1933. If it was destroyed by a bomb during the war then all the posts would've been obliterated already, which was not the case. The city itself was not bombed, much less the wharf! The platform that makes up the runway of the wharf  was made of wood, which were either dismantled or have deteriorated through time.$$I used to go here when I was young, we would then look for "batad" and "sisi". But because of pollution, it's now dirty and full of accumulated trash from the rivers. I hope the government will do something about it because it is really a sight to behold especially during sunset.$$I used to have mangrove rehabilitation and coastal clean up program near the area. For me it's one of the best place to witness a scenic sunset.$$not only silay city has a beautiful  view.

message+desc: Holy crab! The coconut crab (Birgus Latro) or locally known as Tatus is the largest land-living arthropod in the world. It can grow up to 3ft in length from leg to leg and is strong enough to cut through coconut husks with their pincers. Photo taken from Arkive.com
comments:
We have this in Danjugan.$$FYI, these are threatened species.$$These are a protected species, hence consumption of coconut crabs is not allowed by law. Stick to the normal crabs instead, they are equally as good.$$Good lord! Don't wanna mess with that!$$I would love to see one - just not very close.$$Do they have these in Guam ?$$Rose Vel Mancini you seen these on person?$$I lived there for a short period when I was very young and remember seeing crabs in the trees$$Rory- you heard WRONG! Some of my shipmates tried to cook one on the Island of Diego Garcia, and the meat was NASTY!$$Dave Ryan and Andrew are correct. These Coconut Crabs are considered a THREATENED species according to the Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources, "Buying, using, gathering, possessing and/or transporting [this] species are prohibited under Philippine laws (Republic Act No. 8550, Sec. 91, 92 and 97; Fisheries Administrative Order 202 and 208) and international treaty (Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, CITES)."

Thank you!$$Actually, Andrew- normal crabs are better. I tasted Coconut crab in 1983, and it was horrible$$Coconut crab is a delicacy in Vanuatu, curry and coconut milk and bird eye chilli will make the difference..

The busiest place in the Philippines is underwater. It can get a bit crowded, but we like it that way. Visit Puerto Galera, Coron, Anilao, Boracay, Palawan, Dumaguete, Malapascua and Balicasag to meet our aquatic residents.

Fun Fact:
If you don‚Äôt want to get wet, visit Manila Ocean Park instead. It's a world-class marine theme park in the city.

Take a break from the hustle bustle of the city in a Japanese resort area! 
Taketomi Island is the only place in the world with well-preserved traditional Okinawa-style houses with red-tiled roofs and coral stone walls 
Enjoy cycling around the island, and dropping by beautiful Kondoi beach! 
‚ÄúSoki Soba‚Äù the delicious Okinawa noodle with boneless pork ribs on the top will get you ready for a ride on a water buffalo carriage.

http://japan-magazine.jnto.go.jp/en/special_okinawa02.html

[NEW EVENT] 10 Amazing Sights In Toa Payoh You Have To See To Believe

Also - TSL MEET AND GREET + INSTAGRAM WALK!!

There's plenty we don't know about this old estate. Like the time Queen Elizabeth hailed from England to grace our HDB blocks, and that one tree that must never, EVER be cut. 

AND NOW YOU CAN JOIN US TOO EXPLORING THE NEIGHBOURHOOD!

In our third instawalk, the TSL team and the Ministry of National Development takes you on a journey around Toa Payoh. It is completely free to join.

message+desc:
Apl.de.Ap There's a special place in my heart for the Puning Hot Springs. Located just outside of my hometown Pampanga, the Puning Hot Springs lay at the end of a mountain pass reached by 4x4 Jeeps. Once there, my friends and I were treated to a pool of natural hot springs and sand spa.
We feasted like kings and queens to a succulent lechon and lovely chorus of locals. This is something everyone must experience. So come experience my country and enjoy.

#IMFITP #ItsMoreFunInThePhilippines #TourismPromotionalBoard #PuningHotSprings #Pampanga #PhilippinesThere's a special place in my heart for the Puning Hot Springs. message+desc:
Cendrawasih Bay is a large bay in Northern Province of Papua and West Papua, New Guinea, Indonesia. It reveals a great diversity of diving and a real sense of the pioneer spirit. As an indicator of biodiversity, the bay has 4 species of turtle: Green, Hawksbill, Pacific Ridley and Leatherback, as well as much sought-after marine mammals such as dolphins and dugongs. In Cendrawasih Bay you‚Äôll find that whale sharks will come and stay around in pods and you can swim along with them. All in all, those facts makes the Cendrawasih region as a remarkable dive destination for large animals, small animals, beautiful reefs bursting with life and historical World War II wrecks. There‚Äôs no doubt that with such of reputation makes this area as a must-visit destination for so many scuba divers. http://ow.ly/RYGCl

#WonderfulIndonesia #PesonaIndonesia
comments: Beautiful but unfortunately  the more we expose, the more greed people want to ruin our beauty of nature and habitat.$$Going to irian jaya is my dream at the moment

message+desc:
Jangsaengpo in Ulsan, is famous as a whale city. At the Jasaengpo Whale/Life Experience Musuem, visitors can learn about the history of whales and experience diverse dolphin-related programs. Plus, whale-watching is available although you're more likely to see dolphins as Minke whales are endagered species. If you do see one, it's your lucky day! :D

How to get there?

Whale Life Experience Museum: http://bit.ly/1C6Vzdg

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Coron, Palawan

What is it like? 
Coron‚Äôs Kayangan Lake is the cleanest lake in Asia. Here, the warm sea and the cold mountain spring combine to create a pool of clear water perfect for swimming. To add to that, the lake is enclosed by towering limestone mountains. 

How to get there: 
Fly from Manila to Busuanga, then transfer to a van bound for Coron.

Fun Fact: 
Kayangan Lake is a 10-15 minute hike through a scenic, tropical rainforest.

Photo by/Headline by: 
Raul Montifar/Rachel Teotico
comments: captivating! no other else in the world matches the beauty of the Philippines....$$Samuel Soliven Yn Tel been there..haha$$Been there  and were planning to go back again$$I want to experience this place when i get back to phils.$$..you should try it..its really good to experience the cleanest and greenest lake in Asia..     I'm Anthony tour guide in Coron...$$Had been there. Its really beautiful and very relaxing.$$True, the nicest lake I've seen....$$Miss it!it's truly a paradise!

message+desc:
Where is it?
Anilao, Batangas

What is it?
Anilao is regarded as the birthplace of diving in the Philippines. It's popular among divers and snorkelers, not only from the Philippines, but from all over the world.

Fun Fact:
Aside from diving and snorkeling, you can also enjoy other activities in Anilao: island-hopping, water sports or trekking Mt.Gulugod Baboy.

Photo by Kevin Palmer

message+desc:
"The almost circular island of Balicasag off the coast of Bohol is teeming with marine life, and seems to just pop out of nowhere. The area is a marine sanctuary frequented by turtles, dolphins, fish, and occasionally whales. Recently, the largest animal on earth, the blue whale was spotted in the vicinity of these waters."

Words and Photo by Christer Isulat 
@filipino_flight_tales.

#VisitPhilippinesAGAIN2016
#itsmorefuninthePhilippines
comments:
Never knew we had this just around the neighborhood of Leyte. We never really had to search far for world class destinations. Shhhhh....lets keep this a secret from ChinaüòÇ.$$Was there this morning.  The beach was nothing to brag about.    Saw a lot of dolphins on our way there.  Didn't snorkel so didn't see the marine life.  We find islands in Coron much better with white sands and lots of marine life right on the shore especially at Paz Island.  Much cheaper to go Island hopping in Coron.  Bohol is a beautiful Island and so is Panglao, but  quite expensive and no tour packages offered.  We had to pay each and every step from cars, boats, entrance fees to sites, etc.  was a bit disappointed.$$Me being sarcastic: "Don't show this to CHINA or else...." ;) :D$$I haven't been on the island but I went snorkeling in the waters around it during a dolphin watching trip. It was absolutely beautiful.$$Coming to visit Azores via Galera with David Haas in January.. How's this South China Sea dispute affecting you guys with the live aboard and the area?$$Philippines is indeed a rich & beautiful country. It's a pride for us all Filipinos. But it also needs protection from greedy foreign countries aiming for exploitation of its beauty & richness. Please, always be on guard Kabayan.$$I went there last October, we saw lots of giant turtles. Amazing üôÇ$$is it really an islAnd??
it look like paradise$$Cant wait to move there for a month in December. I love Pilipinas$$I've been there 3 decades ago, to conduct inspection on Lighthouse Balicasag. The place is Fronting Tagbilaran City. Can be reached by motorized Banca.$$Jhun Vargas: We've been there, dolphin watching, snorkeling and feeding fish. What a place, no other island can equal.$$And I read an article that there is another land forming in North East of the Philippines. They grab and grab our islands but it seems that there are new islands/islets forming in the coming years! It is Mother Nature.$$Bek Heather Sofie Erin this is where I went diving and saw the whale shark. :-)$$Been there with the kids....beautiful place$$Been there with my family!  It was amazing!!$$travel the world and have freedom life$$Proud that was able to go and swim there!!!  Year 2015 #ILovePhilippines #TravelPamore
